LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Islamic Republic of Afghanistan 
   
Proposal   The  proposed  Fiscal  Management  and  Public  Administration 
Reform Program (FMPARP) subprogram 1 is a cluster program. It 
consists of (i) a program cluster for the FMPARP of $105 million; 
(ii) a program loan of $48 million from the Asian Development 
Bank’s (ADB’s) Special Funds resources for fiscal management 
and public administration policy reforms for subprogram 1 (the 
Program); and (iii) a grant for Capacity Building for Institutional 
Development  (the  Project  or  Grant)  of  $7  million  to  support 
targeted interventions to implement the Program. 
   
Classification  Targeting Classification: General intervention 
Sector: Law, economic management, and public policy 
Subsector: Public finance and expenditure management 
Themes: Sustainable economic growth, governance  
Subthemes: Promoting macroeconomic stability, financial and 
economic governance 
   
Environment  Category C 
Assessment 
   
Rationale  The Government is in the midst of finalizing its interim Afghanistan 
national development strategy (I-ANDS). A major focus of this 
work is laying the foundations for sound institutions and effective 
policies to support the implementation of a sustainable medium-
term development framework. 
  
Two key reform initiatives will be strengthening fiscal reforms and 
establishing and implementing a legal and regulatory framework 
for  a  new  civil  service.  Strengthening  fiscal  reforms—including 
improving revenue collection, establishing medium-term fiscal and 
budgeting  frameworks,  and  developing  a  public  expenditure 
management system—is essential to strengthen the budget so it 
can become the central instrument of policy making. The ANDS 
needs to be linked to the public investment program (PIP) if the 
Government’s  development  priorities  are  to  be  achieved. 
Establishing  and  implementing  a  legislative  and  administrative 
framework, including reforming and restructuring key agencies, 
developing human resource management, and determining the  
structure for a new pay and grading system—will enhance the 
absorptive capacity of the civil service. 
 
  These reforms will help to address the current situation where (i) a 
large  proportion  of  the  external  budget  is  funded  directly  by 
donors and executed beyond Government budgetary controls and 
(ii)  weak  Government  capacity  is  an  obstacle  to  a  more 
Government-owned budget linked to policy priorities, including the

ii 
  achievement  of  the  Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs). 
Strengthening fiscal management will mean more resources will 
be available for key public goods such as education and health, 
which will benefit poverty reduction.  
 
Measures  to  improve  the  Government’s  overall  financial 
management accountability framework, including strengthening of 
fiduciary controls, will help reduce corruption and the diversion of 
resources from intended recipients. This will reassure donors and 
encourage  them  to  channel  more  resources  through  the 
Government budget.  
   
Subprogram 1 will develop systems and procedures to strengthen 
fiscal  management  and  public  administration.  These  measures 
will complement the integrated government financial management 
information system (IGFMIS) to be financed by the World Bank. 
Subprogram 2 will build on these reforms and focus on improving 
provision and delivery of public goods and services in order to 
achieve  the  country’s  social  development  objectives—as 
entrenched in the MDGs. 
   
Estimated FMPARP  FMPARP subprogram 1 is to be completed by December 2008. 
Completion Date  Subprogram 2 is expected to be completed by December 2011. 
   
Program Loan Objectives  The Program will develop systems and procedures—supported by 
increased capacity—to improve budget programming, strengthen 
resource mobilization, develop the civil service, and enhance the 
monitoring of public finances.  
 
It  will  strengthen  (i)  the  budgeting  framework,  (ii)  the  public 
investment program, (iii) revenue mobilization, (iv) civil service 
management,  (v)  the  functioning  of  provincial  administrations, 
(vi) the transparency and accountability of public finances, and 
(vii) treasury management. 
 
Financing Plan  A loan of $48 million from the Special Funds resources of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) will be provided. The loan will 
have a 40-year term, including a grace period of 10 years, an 
interest charge of 1% per annum during the repayment period and 
such other conditions as set forth in the draft loan agreement. The 
total amount of the interest charge during the grace period will be 
capitalized and charged to the loan account. 
 
  Subprogram  2,  which  will  be  presented  separately  for 
consideration  and  approval  by  the  Board  and  will  depend  on 
progress with subprogram 1, is expected to require a loan of $50 
million from ADB’s Special Funds resources. Subprogram 2 is 
expected to be implemented from December 2008 to December 
2011.

iii 
Period and Tranching  The  Program  period  will  be  3  years,  from  December  2005  to 
December 2008. The loan will be released in two equal tranches 
of $24 million each. The first tranche will be released upon loan 
effectiveness  or  shortly  thereafter,  upon  compliance  with  first 
tranche  release  conditions.  The  second  is  expected  to  be 
released  within  24  months  of  the  release  of  the  first  tranche, 
subject to compliance with second tranche release conditions.

Executing Agency and  The  Executing  Agency  (EA)  of  the  Program  loan  will  be  the 
Implementation  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF).  MOF  will  set  up  an  interagency 
Arrangements  implementation and coordination committee (IICC) headed by the 
Deputy  Minister  of  Finance-Budget  and  Treasury  Management 
and  comprising  representatives  from  the  Budget  Department, 
Treasury  Department,  fiscal  policy  unit,  Revenue  Department, 
Customs  Department,  Public  Enterprises  Department,  and 
Independent Administrative Reform and Civil Service Commission 
(IARCSC). Heads of Moustufiats of major provinces (provincial 
offices at the MOF responsible for revenue collection and carrying 
out treasury functions) shall be co-opted as a member as and 
when necessary. ADB will be invited to attend the IICC meetings 
on a “as needs basis” when relevant issues are to be discussed. 
Regular reporting of minutes of IICC will be provided to ADB. The 
IICC will meet at least quarterly to monitor and coordinate the 
FMPARP  to  ensure  the  reforms  are  being  implemented 
effectively. 
   
Procurement  The  loan  proceeds  will  be  used  to  finance  the  full  foreign 
exchange cost of items produced and procured in ADB member 
countries,  excluding  ineligible  items,  and  imports  financed  by 
other bilateral and multilateral sources. In accordance with the 
provisions of ADB’s Simplification of Disbursement Procedures 
and Related Requirements for Program Loans, the proceeds of 
the loan will be disbursed to the Government as the Borrower. 
The Government will certify that the volume of eligible imports 
exceeds the amount of ADB’s projected disbursements under the 
loan for the given period. It is expected that the loan proceeds will 
be  utilized over  a  period  of  36 months  from the  date  of  loan 
effectiveness. ADB reserves the right to audit the use of the loan 
proceeds  and  to  verify  the  accuracy  of  the  Government’s 
certification.  Loan  proceeds  may  be  used  to  finance  eligible 
imports for which expenditures were incurred 180 days before the 
loan becomes effective. 
 
Counterpart Funds  Counterpart funds generated from the loan will be used to meet 
Program expenditures and associated costs.

iv 
Grant Objectives  The grant will support capacity building of the MOF, IARCSC, and 
priority  ministries.  It  will  (i)  strengthen  the  budget  process; 
(ii) improve  the  capacity  of  the  moustufiats;  (iii)  support 
implementation of the civil service law; and (iv) carry out cash 
management, establishment of an accounting policy, and treasury 
bills development.  
   
Financing Plan  A grant of $7 million will be provided from ADB’s Special Funds 
resources. The grant will be subject to conditions set forth in the 
draft grant agreement. 
   
Executing Agency and  MOF and IARCSC will oversee and coordinate the implementation 
Implementation  of  the  Project  through  delegation  to  (i)  the  IICC,  and  (ii)  the 
Arrangements  program  director  (a  domestic  consultant)  who  will  work  with 
designated department coordinators and who will report to the 
Deputy Minister of Finance-Budget and Treasury Management. 
   
Consulting Services  Consultants will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines 
on  the  Use  of  Consultants.  A  total  of  172  person-months  of 
international  and  300  person-months  of  domestic  consulting 
inputs will be required. The quality-based selection (QBS) method 
will be used to select consultants for specific components.   
   
Subprogram 1 Benefits  Subprogram 1 will improve the capacity of the MOF, IARCSC, and 
and Beneficiaries  moustufiats  to  (i)  collect  revenues  efficiently,  (ii)  direct  public 
resources effectively to meet priority needs, and (iii) monitor the 
flow of resources and evaluate the impact of public spending.  
 
  Subprogram  1  will  support  fiscal  management  and  public 
administration reforms that will enable the country to manage the 
transition  from  emergency  response  to  long-term  sustainable 
development.  Improvements  in  the  budget  process,  financial 
management processes, and fiduciary control mechanisms are 
likely to encourage more donors to channel funding through the 
Government budget. This will, in turn, lead to further institutional 
strengthening  and  state  building,  which  is  essential  to  the 
consolidation of peace. FMPARP will encourage the Government 
to adopt a more participatory approach to the budgeting process, 
enhancing ownership, and promoting a more efficient resource 
allocation process. More efficient allocation of public resources 
will be essential for poverty reduction and the achievement of the 
MDGs.  
 
Direct beneficiaries will include the Government itself and officials, 
who will gain valuable exposure to consultants in implementing 
the reform agenda and will benefit from training. Nongovernment 
organizations will benefit from the system of standards that will be 
developed  under  subprogram  2  to  strengthen  outsourcing  of 
service delivery.

v 
  Over  the  longer  term,  FMPARP  will  strengthen  governance  in 
Afghanistan, including greater involvement by the state in raising 
revenues and financing development. Taxpayers and importers 
will benefit from a clearer, simplified, and more balanced tax and 
customs administration. Those segments of the population most 
dependent  on  public  goods  and  services—including  people  in 
more remote areas—can expect an eventual improvement in the 
quality  of  these  services,  resulting  from  reduced  waste, 
duplication, and other nonproductive use of public resources. The 
private sector will gain from improved public services. Overall, 
FMPARP will contribute to economic growth and poverty reduction 
in Afghanistan. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  External  risks  include  (i)  security,  (ii)  political,  and  (iii) 
macroeconomic  risks.  Internal  risks  include  (i)  capacity 
constraints, (ii) governance, and (iii) donor coordination.   
 
Security  concerns  pose  the  largest  risk.  A  worsening  security 
situation would have many impacts on FMPARP, including limiting 
the extension of reforms to the subnational level of government. If 
the security situation deteriorates, operations will be restricted and 
fielding consultants and monitoring missions will be more difficult.  
 
Political  risks  appear  to  be  contained,  following  successful 
parliamentary  and  provincial  elections.  However,  in  a  more 
politicized  environment,  decisive  policy  decisions  may  not  be 
based on technical merit alone. 
 
Macroeconomic risks have been reduced, following progress in 
building  supporting  infrastructure  to  ensure  effective 
macroeconomic  management  and  overall  improvement  in 
macroeconomic stabilization efforts.  
 
Capacity  constraints  are  the  most  significant  internal  risks, 
because  of  the  limited  availability  of  skilled  resources  to 
implement the reform program.  
 
Governance risks include the power of vested interests. Revenue 
administration officials may be co-opted by interests that refuse to 
embrace change or by enterprises that want to override the legal 
system. There may also be scope for corruption. 
 
Donor coordination risks are acute in Afghanistan, where there is 
a significant donor presence in most ministries. Unless there is 
strong Government ownership of the reforms, combined with well- 
coordinated programs, there is a risk of duplication and ineffective 
assistance. 
 
These risks will be mitigated in the following ways. FMPARP will 
develop  human  resource  management  policies  across  key 
ministries  that  directly  address  the   weak   capacity.   The grant

vi 
  component  is  particularly  designed  to  strengthen  capacity  and 
institutional development. 
 
  FMPARP  will  support  efforts  to  strengthen  macroeconomic 
stability through improving revenue collection and fiscal discipline. 
Enhancing revenue mobilization will reduce the risk of disruption 
and dependence on foreign assistance over the medium term.  
 
Other safeguards include coordinated and complementary reform 
programs  supported  by  other  donors,  including  an  IMF  Staff 
Monitored Program that is likely to be extended for another year, 
and may be upgraded to a Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility. 
The World Bank is expected to approve a second Programmatic 
Support for Institution Building loan. This would cover a broad 
range  of  reforms  from  procurement  policy  to  financial 
management.  The  World  Bank  is  also  expected  to  approve  a 
second Public Administration and Capacity Building loan for public 
administration  reforms  and  support  for  the  procurement  of  an 
IGFMIS.  In  addition,  the  World  Bank  has  approved  a  Public 
Financial Management Performance Report for Afghanistan that 
monitors  the  Government’s  efforts  to  strengthen  performance 
across  28  public  financial  management  indicators.  The 
Department for International Development of the United Kingdom, 
and  the  United  States  Agency  for  International  Development 
programs  are  involved  in  areas  closely  related  to  FMPARP, 
including revenue administration and reforms to the civil service 
and state-owned enterprises.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  the  Fiscal 
Management and Public Administration Reform Program (FMPARP) in the Islamic Republic of 
Afghanistan  comprising  (i)  a  proposed  program  cluster  on  fiscal  management  and  public 
administration reforms in Afghanistan, (ii) a proposed program loan for subprogram 1 of the 
FMPARP  (the  Program)  and  (iii)  a  proposed  grant  for  Capacity  Building  for  Institutional 
Development (the Project or the Grant).    
 
II.  THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 
 
2.  Afghanistan has made significant progress in achieving macroeconomic stability over the 
last 3 years. Gross domestic product (GDP) is estimated to have grown by 28.6% in fiscal year 
(FY) 2003 and by 15.7% in FY2004. In FY2005, growth is estimated to have slowed to 8.0%, 
largely because of a decline in agricultural output as a result of a drought. The economy is 
highly reliant on agriculture (37.2% of GDP, excluding opium production, in FY2005) and on the 
service sector (38.3%). Sectors linked to the reconstruction effort, such as construction and 
telecommunications,  continued  to  perform  well  in  FY2005.  Since  the  successful  currency 
conversion in early 2003, prices have remained broadly stable and the exchange rate has 
fluctuated around AF45–50 per dollar, reflecting widespread acceptance of the new currency 
and prudent macroeconomic and monetary policies. However, the opium economy has grown to 
record  levels  and  this  poses  one  of  the  country's  most  difficult  development  challenges. 
According to the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC), opium cultivation in 2004 
increased by 64%, which amounted to about 60% of the country's official GDP (see Appendix 1 
for key economic indicators). In 2005, opium production has fallen because of lower farm-gate 
prices and initial successes in the antinarcotics campaign. 
 
3.  The operating budget for FY2005 was set at $609 million, with $300 million to be 
generated  from  domestic  revenue  and  $309  million  to  be  covered  by  foreign  assistance. 
Domestic revenues met the more conservative target under the International Monetary Fund 
(IMF) Staff Monitored Program (SMP), although they were below the budget forecast. Custom 
duties, which represent about 55% of total revenues, rose by 20%. As in the previous year, 
operating expenditures also fell short of the budget targets. For instance, because of continued 
delays in recruiting teachers and in implementing the main civil service restructuring program, 
expenditures were AF2.4 billion short of the midyear review projection of AF29.1 billion. The 
development budget, approved with a delay, increased from $1.8 billion in FY2004 to $4.2 
billion in FY2005. Development budget spending has been very slow and continues to be 
hampered by the volatile security situation; capacity constraints, particularly in line ministries; 
and the long lead time required for project design. 
 
4.  The  consumer  price  index  (CPI)  rose  by  16.3%  in  FY2005  (year-on-year  change) 
reflecting the above average price of wheat because of the drought and sharp increases in 
housing prices. Monetary policy continues to focus on keeping inflation under control and on 
ensuring a relatively stable exchange rate. A regime of foreign exchange auctions is in place. 
The Central Bank successfully introduced a short-term capital note in September 2004 and 
reserve  requirements  for  commercial  banks  have  been  adopted.  Afghanistan's  financial 
infrastructure, including savings and investment instruments, is still largely undeveloped. The 
amount of currency in circulation is estimated to have grown by 40.9% in FY2004 and by 37.5% 
in FY2005, reflecting strong inflows of development assistance funds while maintaining a 5% 
exchange rate trading band. Foreign reserves amounted to approximately $1.3 billion at the end

2 
of FY2005, reflecting 3.7 months of import coverage, an increase from $815 million the previous 
year.  
 
5.  Reliable balance of payment data are not available. Exports of goods (excluding opium, 
and including re-exports) reached $1.66 billion in FY2005. Total imports amounted to $3.87 
billion. According to UNODC, the value of opiate exports to neighboring countries increased 
from $2.3 billion in 2003 to $2.8 billion in 2004. The current account deficit (excluding grants) is 
expected to amount to $2.7 billion (45.0% of GDP) in FY2005. The deficit was covered mainly 
by grants (if grants are included, the deficit was 0.7% of GDP).1  
 
6.  Despite the strong economic recovery and progress in structural reforms, the remaining 
challenges  are  huge.  If  Afghanistan  is  to  shift  from  recovery-related  growth  to  long-term 
sustainable development, it will require new drivers of growth, continued commitment to the 
ambitious reform agenda, and sustained support from the international community. With a per 
capita GDP of only $253 per annum in FY2005, reducing poverty, or even attaining the income 
levels of neighboring countries, will require strong economic growth over the medium and long 
term and substantial international assistance. Given the size of the opium economy, a holistic 
strategy that creates alternative livelihoods in the rural economy, combined with interdiction and 
eradication measures and legal reform, is needed, supported by broad-based economic growth 
and sustained donor commitment. Finally, because of its limited capacity to deliver public goods 
and services, the Government will require concerted actions with donors and civil society to 
create a sustainable environment of good governance to ensure effective service delivery. This 
will contribute to improved livelihoods and poverty reduction.  
 
III.  THE SECTOR: PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Sector Description and Government’s Reform Program 
 
7.  Following the collapse of the Taliban regime in 2001, the transitional administration, 
assisted by a large donor-funded reconstruction program, embarked on rebuilding the core 
functions of government. In the immediate postconflict stage, the strategic challenge for the 
Government  was  to  move  swiftly  to  strengthen  security  and  stability  while  creating  the 
foundations for effective government based on strong economic management and improved 
delivery of public goods and services.  
 
8.  On the economic management front, key achievements in the early years included 
establishing (i) a two-tier banking system, centered on the Central Bank overseeing inflation 
stabilization and the issuance of a new currency, the afghani; (ii) a budget formulation and 
implementation process; (iii) an expenditure framework based on national priority programs; 
(iv) a revenue administration centered on the customs department and a large-taxpayer office; 
and (v) a treasury management system that operates at the provincial level through moustufiats2 
and is based on expenditure controls through the treasury single account (TSA).  
 
9.  To  improve  delivery  of  public  goods  and  services,  the  Government  focused  on 
strengthening the capacity of the executive and key line ministries at the central level. This was 
combined with the outsourcing of service delivery to nongovernment organizations (NGOs) and 
other arrangements as required. An important pillar of this strategy was the strengthening of 
public administration through greater incentives to attract and retain qualified staff, such as the

B.  Performance 
 
10.  The strong economic growth performance over the last few years was supported by a 
commitment to an ambitious reform agenda. The structural adjustment reforms (para. 8) have 
led to a stronger economy with GDP growth averaging just over 17% per annum from FY2003 
to FY2005. This reflects the effects of donor-driven development assistance combined with 
improved—although still somewhat tenuous—security conditions spurring consumption demand 
and – through better business opportunities – investment. Consumption remains strong, and 
was estimated to have been 105% of GDP in FY2005. Gross fixed capital formation was 
estimated to have been 39% of GDP during the same period.  
 
11.  On the political front, the country's first democratic presidential elections in October 2004 
were  met  by  high  voter  turnout  and  without  major  security  incidents.  Incumbent  interim 
President Hamid Karzai was confirmed as Afghanistan's first democratically elected President. 
This was followed by parliamentary and provincial council elections in September 2005.3 These 
elections are expected to further advance the democratic process in Afghanistan and to lay the 
foundations for greater political stability. 
 
12.  In April 2002, the Government adopted a national development framework (NDF). The 
NDF focuses on three pillars: (i) security and human development, (ii) physical infrastructure, 
and (iii) an enabling environment for development. For each pillar, broad sector programs have 
been developed and in-country consultative groups (CGs) have been established to select 
projects and coordinate foreign aid flows. National priority strategies and public investment 
programs (PIPs) across 16 sectors have laid the groundwork for prioritized public investment 
and  sustainable  medium-term  growth.  The  NDF  also  formed  the  basis  for  Securing 
Afghanistan's  Future:  Accomplishments  and  the  Strategic  Path  Forward,  the  Government’s 
previous development strategy, which was presented at the Berlin Conference on Afghanistan 
in March 2004. In mid-2005, the Government started work on the interim Afghanistan national 
development strategy (I-ANDS) which will also constitute the interim poverty reduction strategy. 
A full ANDS will be developed over the course of 2006. The ANDS will update and integrate 
strategies for (i) reducing poverty, (ii) generating wealth and sustained economic growth, and 
(iii)  promoting  social  inclusion.  The  process  will  include  widespread  consultation  and  the 
development of a 3-year macroeconomic and fiscal framework. A draft I-ANDS is expected to 
be developed by December 2005 and presented formally at a donors’ conference in London in 
January 2006.  
 
13.  Securing Afghanistan’s Future (SAF), argued that an average of 9% growth per annum 
in the non-drug economy (10–15% in the short term and 7–9% in the long term) is needed over 
the next 15 years to ensure a visible improvement in economic and social conditions while the 
drug economy is gradually eliminated. During the Berlin conference, donors pledged $8.2 billion 
for March 2004–2007, equivalent to 69% of the $11.9 billion Government target. Under SAF, the 
private sector is expected to be the primary engine of growth and employment opportunities. 
Support mechanisms for the private sector will have to be strengthened and progress made to 
strengthen  legal  foundations  for  property  rights,  contract  enforcement,  bankruptcy,  and

14.  To achieve the Government's growth targets over the medium term and to replace opium 
production gradually, development needs to be more broad-based and sustainable. Decreasing 
donor funds and increasing demands on the Government budget mean that domestic revenue 
efforts  need  to  be  stepped  up  significantly.  The  Government’s  ability  to  meet  the  many 
challenges will depend on the continuation of political and legal reforms, an improving security 
situation,  and  sound  fiscal  and  economic  policies.  Improving  capacity  throughout  the 
Government will be essential for all of these reforms.   
 
15.  Since  March  2004,  the  Government  has  been  implementing  the  IMF-led  SMP  to 
maintain macroeconomic and financial stability, pursue structural reforms, and build statistical 
capacity. Performance during the first year of the SMP was strong and most targets were met. 
The fifth quarterly review (April–June 2005) confirmed that the Program remains on track and it 
has  been  extended  another  year  to  September  2006.  It  may  be  upgraded  to  a  Poverty 
Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF) in 2006 following approval of the ANDS. 
 
C.  Issues and Opportunities 
 
16.  Over  the  past  4  years,  development  assistance  has  concentrated  on  building  the 
supporting infrastructure for economic management in Afghanistan. In this period and given the 
focus on emergency management, trade-offs were made that may have led to capacity building 
being substituted by international consultancy inputs. There is now a growing perception of the 
need to move towards a medium-term sustainable development framework with increasing 
country ownership of policies and greater domestic capacity. Day-to-day management in key 
ministries needs to be reoriented toward forward-looking strategies. More effective institutions 
will be needed and capacity strengthened throughout Government. There will be a gradual 
movement towards a greater focus on sustainable development. 
 
17.  The success of this transition will largely depend on two key initiatives: deepening 
structural reforms and strengthening capacity throughout the civil service. The deepening of 
structural  reforms—including  improving  revenue  collection,  establishing  a  medium-term 
budgeting framework, and developing a public expenditure management system—are to sustain 
economic growth and attain poverty reduction objectives. Strengthening capacity throughout the 
civil service will enhance the Government’s capability to implement and deepen reforms and 
promote sound economic management. The Government recognizes that these reforms will 
need to be designed under a structured and programmatic approach under a common policy 
framework if they are to have a lasting impact on the provision of public goods and services. A 
vision paper was prepared by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) in collaboration with various donors 
that sets out the strategic challenges and objectives for the ministry over the next 5 years.  
 
18.  The  following  section  analyzes  the  critical  constraints  on  FMPARP  (see  also  the 
summary sector analysis in Appendix 2). The proposed reforms are discussed in Section IV.  
 
1.  Fiscal Management 
 
19.  The Government has stressed the importance of the budget as the principal instrument 
of policy and reform and has urged donors to increasingly channel funds through the budget. In 
FY2005,  only  $1.7  billion  out  of  a  total  of  $5.1  billion  was  implemented  directly  by  the 
Government through the budget ($1.3 billion of which remained under direct donor supervision

5 
and fiduciary oversight). Most donors continue to channel resources directly to NGOs and/or 
private agencies through special funds and other arrangements. This is particularly evident in 
the health sector, where NGOs, directly funded by donors, run the health care services in most 
provinces.  The  percentage  of  funding  that  lies  outside  Government  budgetary  controls, 
combined with weak Government capacity, makes it difficult to move towards a more policy-
oriented budget.4 To address this issue, the budget process will have to be strengthened. 
Fiduciary controls and overall financial management must be strengthened, so donors feel 
confident enough to channel more resources through the Government budget. At the same 
time,  Government  capacity  and  coordination  mechanisms  will  have  to  be  enhanced  so 
development plans can be translated into properly designed investment programs and projects. 
 
20.  Weak  Policy  Formulation  and  Implementation  Capacity.  Sound  macroeconomic 
management  is  critical  to  support  stabilization  in  any  postconflict  transition  phase.  In 
Afghanistan, (i) managing large inflows of donor funds; (ii) pursuing structural reforms, including 
price liberalization; and (iii) rooting out the underground opium economy are challenging for any 
policy  maker.  Policy  instruments  are  in  many  cases  at  an  early  stage  of  development 
(e.g., liquidity management instruments) or are being adopted in parallel with the introduction of 
the legal and regulatory framework (e.g., budget, tax, customs, and civil service laws and 
supporting regulations). 
 
21.  Slow  Disbursement/Weak  Budget  Implementation.  Limited  absorptive  capacity 
constrains Government efforts to roll out service delivery and make effective use of public 
resources for reconstruction. Operating expenditures and “core” budget development spending, 
which includes donor-funded projects administered through Government accounts, continue to 
be below budget targets. In FY2005, for instance, delays in recruiting national teachers and in 
the civil service restructuring program led to significant underspending. Similarly, development 
budget spending has been consistently behind target and continues to be hampered by the 
volatile security situation and capacity constraints, particularly in line ministries and at the 
provincial level. Further, multiyear projects are typically characterized by a lengthy start-up 
period (e.g., for the preparation of feasibility studies).  
 
22.  Parallel Budget Processes. The budget currently consists of an operating core budget 
where funds are channeled through the Treasury and a donor-funded external budget. The core 
budget is divided into the operating budget and the development budget. The development 
budget is wholly dependent on external sourcing and, because of delays in confirming donor 
commitments, is prepared and approved after the beginning of the fiscal year. This creates 
significant difficulties as resources are unpredictable and timely project preparation very difficult. 
The budget cycles for the operating and development budgets are still not synchronized, which 
causes difficulties in budget programming, including proper identification of resources for the 
recurrent costs of investment projects. Budgeting for multi-year investment projects is very 
complicated. Currently the implications of investment expenditure on the operating budget are 
not considered when making the decision to invest through the development budget. Delays in 
budget preparation and approval have led to delays in wage payments at the start of the fiscal 
year, although this should not be an issue following the approval of the interim operating budget 
for FY2006 before the start of the fiscal year.  
 
                                                 
4  In most countries, donor assistance is channeled through the recipient country’s national budget. This serves to 
reinforce the Government’s priorities under its national development strategy. If resources are not coursed through 
the budget, the degree of Government ownership and commitment is undermined as it is not fully in control of 
development expenditures.

6 
23.  Lack of a Multi-Year Framework. While significant progress has been made over the 
last 2 years, budget programming is still in its early stages. There is a need to develop a 
medium-term fiscal program that attempts to project expenditure and revenues over the medium 
term  (i.e.,  the  next  3  years).  Multi-year  aggregate  fiscal  forecasts  are  updated  annually. 
However, current expenditure estimates are only at the aggregate level. Domestic revenue 
projections are targets rather than tight estimates based on forecasting models that would take 
into account the economic results of specific policy actions. Accordingly, midyear reviews often 
reduce programmed spending and revenues. For the first time, in FY2006 line ministries will be 
required to prepare multiyear projections as part of budget preparation. There is also limited 
analysis of how policy decisions (e.g., wage increases or pension commutation) or external 
factors (e.g., oil price shocks or security constraints) can affect spending plans. 
 
24.  Lack  of  Budget  Comprehensiveness.  Revenues5  and  expenditures6  of  public 
enterprises are  considered  to  be  outside  the  national  budget.  However,  public  enterprises 
represent a significant financial holding, and the state as the sole or majority owner bears the 
impact of their financial operations. In Afghanistan, public enterprises control essential physical 
assets in almost all sectors of the economy.7 According to a survey in October 2004, the public 
enterprise sector is composed of 78 enterprises:8 6 banks, 1 insurance company, and 71 non-
financial enterprises engaged in agriculture, manufacturing, industry, and services. In addition, 
there are a number of other non-financial Government-controlled commercial entities, including 
Ariana  Airlines,  as  well  a  broad  range  of  activities  of  commercial  nature  that  are  being 
undertaken by various Government departments. However, there is very limited information on 
these entities. The MOF has little consolidated information on the transfer of public finances to 
public enterprises and other Government-controlled commercial entities, partly because of a 
lack of financial reporting, and partly because of inconsistencies in the Government’s treatment 
of them. The lack of a governance framework allows room for corruption. 
 
25.  Current incomplete data indicate that transfers (i.e., subsidies) to public enterprises 
amounted to an estimated AF25 million in FY2003, AF128 million in FY2004, and AF28 million 
in the first half of FY2005. In addition to the declared transfers, there are likely to be untracked 
transfers, such as salaries of staff of public enterprises which are included as part of ministries’ 
payrolls and possible contingent liabilities such as arrears on payment of salaries and pensions, 
and Government guarantees. “Subsidies” may also arise when ministries are obliged to buy 
from public enterprises and public enterprises receive preference when they bid on Government 
contracts. Without fiduciary controls in place, resources may be diverted and corrupt practices 
encouraged. 
 
26.  Budget Allocations across Provinces. The current budget process does not include 
allocation mechanisms to distribute resources to provinces. In essence, this is done by line 
ministries,  which  decide  on  expenditure  allocations  for  each  province.  This  raises  several 
issues. The Government is not making full use of its tax and spending powers to meet socio-
economic regional development objectives, including powers to distribute resources. Although

27.  Limited Capacity at Moustufiats. Any effective extension of public goods and services 
will require strengthening of provincial administrations to ensure that essential public goods and 
services reach people throughout the country. Currently, a small share of potential tax revenues 
is  collected  by  moustufiats.  About  60%  of  national  tax  revenue  is  collected  at  customs 
checkpoints at province borders. These revenues are remitted to moustufiats or provincial tax 
collection offices and subsequently deposited in the TSA. Effective revenue collection implies 
clearer coordination between the Customs Department in Kabul, the moustufiats, and the actual 
checkpoints, in addition to better enforcement capabilities. Moustufiats are also responsible for 
payment and treasury functions at the provincial level.  
 
28.  Budget  Coherence  with  Development  Strategy  and  PIPs.  The  transition  from 
emergency response to long-term sustainable development needs to be underwritten by a 
robust  economic  development  strategy.  The  NDF  of  April  2002,  which  was  subsequently 
confirmed and further refined in Securing Afghanistan’s Future (SAF) in 2004, outlines the 
Government’s development strategy. The NDF contains a list of national priority programs 
(NPPs). At present, the Government is finalizing an NDF update that will also form the basis of 
the I-ANDS.  
 
29.  NPPs operate within the framework of 16 public investment programs (PIPs). They are 
organized around (i) security and human development, (ii) physical infrastructure, and (iii) an 
enabling  environment  for  development.  The  NPPs  are  steered  by  budget,  steering,  and 
oversight committees. Program implementation units (PIU) for each NPP are responsible for 
coordination as well as for financial and operational performance. The consultative group (CG) 
will continue to serve as the principal consultative forum for discussions on progress, policies, 
and  cross-cutting  concerns  that  affect  a  particular  NPP.  A  review  of  the  CG  is  currently 
underway. See Appendix 3 for a more detailed description of CGs. 
 
30.  The NPPs are meant to provide a strategic framework for donor-funded investment 
projects and for the development budget. Similarly, the PIP represents a menu of projects that is 
only gradually being prioritized. In many cases, criteria for including projects on PIP are based 
on the ministry’s capacity to implement the Project, rather than on economic returns or strategic 
complementarities from the investment.  
 
31.  Limited  Revenue  Mobilization  Capacity.  The  Government’s  objective,  according  to 
SAF, is to cover the wage bill by FY2009 and all operating expenditures by FY2014. According 
to the more recent medium-term fiscal framework (MTFF), domestic revenue as a share of 
operating expenditure, is projected to reach 98.7% by FY2010. In FY2005, the revenue to GDP 
ratio was about 4.5% and it is projected to reach 12.5% by FY2015. However, achieving this 
ambitious target will require a substantial increase in revenue collection efforts and careful 
macroeconomic management. Progress has been made in domestic revenue generation, which 
increased from $132 million in FY2003 to $207 million in FY2004 and reached about $265 
million in FY2005. New tax policy reform measures were enacted in early 2004 including a final 
wage withholding tax on higher income employees, an improved income tax regime, and a 
limited range of consumption taxes on services such as telecommunications, air travel, hotels

8 
and restaurants. A large-taxpayer office has been established, although there has been limited 
success on corporate income tax collection. According to the FY2006 midyear budget review, 
total domestic revenue is projected at $468 million, corresponding to an increase of 41% over 
the $333 million in projected revenues at the beginning of the fiscal year.9 Approximately 50% of 
the operating budget and 100% of the development budget are expected to be financed by 
foreign assistance.10 
 
32.  Growth in the overall wage bill has far outpaced growth in domestic revenue generation. 
The wage bill (already about 60% of the operating budget) is expected to increase more 
moderately over the coming years despite pressures from the recruitment of teachers, civil 
service pay increases11 related to the implementation of the PRR, and police pay increases. 
Moreover, it has been proposed that funding for the Afghan National Army (ANA), currently 
financed by external grants, be incorporated into the core budget over the coming years, which 
will pose problems for the Government unless external funding continues. 
 
33.  As part of the Government’s efforts to shore up revenues, a new customs code and 
amendment to the Revenue Law were recently approved. The amendment includes provisions 
on:  (i)  access  powers,  penalties,  offences,  collection  enforcement,  and  record-keeping 
requirements; (ii) corporate tax reforms and provisions for extractive industries; and (iii) a new 
airport departure fee. These measures are expected to place revenue collection on a sounder 
and more sustainable footing.12  
 
  2.  Public Administration  
 
34.  The public administration reform (PAR) program has seven major components, including 
institutional  and  functional  streamlining,  the  civil  service  legal  framework,  and  personnel 
management. The objective of the PAR is to build a sound legal, administrative, and physical 
environment  so  civil  servants  can  function  effectively  and  be  held  accountable  for  their 
performance.  Overall  responsibility  and  coordination  of  PAR  rests  with  the  Independent 
Administrative  Reform  and  Civil  Service  Commission  (IARCSC).  The  priority  reform  and 
restructuring (PRR) initiative provides a framework for implementing the first generation PAR 
program.  
 
35.  PAR has two subprograms: public administration reform and governance (PARG) and 
economic and financial management. The strategic priority of PARG is to strengthen policy 
development capacity within ministries and to focus on the core functions of government. Over 
8,000 civil service posts in “reformed” departments will became eligible for higher salaries and 
of these, about 600 senior posts are being filled through an open competitive process under the 
supervision of the Independent Appointments Board (IAB). The strategic priority of economic 
and financial management is to complete the annual operating and development budgets based

36.  The PRR program is an asymmetric and incremental civil service reform program and, 
more generally, a promoter of change management in Government. It is supported by the World 
Bank.  Approved  PRR  proposals  range  from  creating  new  agencies  to  restoring  basic 
operational  services.  PRR  is  built  around  creating  short-term  capacity  within  ministries  to 
promote policy reform, while setting the groundwork for institutional strengthening. The PRR 
follows a two-stage approach. In stage 1, ministries make proposals to be considered for the 
PRR to the IARCSC. Proposals highlight function, skills mix, and the task force that is in place 
to lead and manage the restructuring process. The administrative reform service evaluates the 
proposal and submits recommendations to the chairman, IARCSC, who, in consultation with the 
ministerial  advisory  committee  makes  a  final  decision  on  whether  or  not  to  present  the 
application  for  stage  2  consideration.  Stage  2  consists  of  ministries  making  proposals  for 
increased pay levels according to the interim additional allowance (IAA) scale. Proposals should 
be based on a detailed proposal on expected improvements in efficiency and cost-effectiveness 
and  should  have  been  agreed  by  MOF.  Recently,  the  ministerial  advisory  committee  has 
required that the applying ministry should have in place a broader strategic plan for the ministry. 
Positions are filled by open competition and appointments are made by the IAB. There are 
probationary periods and annual reviews of performance. A super-scale category in excess of 
IAA has also been introduced for individuals with exceptional qualifications.  
 
37.  The PRR has provided insights on specific challenges and opportunities for rebuilding 
the  machinery  of  government  and  on  the  appropriate  institutional  mechanisms  for  political 
oversight of PAR. The Government is developing a second-generation PAR program as an 
integral  part  of  the  development  of  the  ANDS.  New  institutional  mechanisms  for  political 
oversight and for strengthened donor coordination will be an integral part of the next generation 
of PAR and will be supported by the World Bank and others. The legal framework provided by 
the recently approved Civil Service Law will feature heavily in the second generation PAR 
program and help formalize and strengthen many reforms initiated through the PRR process.  
 
38.  Lack of Coordination Mechanisms and Capacity. Coordination of reconstruction and 
development activities remains weak. Some ministries, including the Ministry of Interior and the 
Ministry of Rural Rehabilitation and Development have established coordination mechanisms at 
provincial  and  district  levels.  These  mechanisms  strengthen  coordination  within  specific 
programs,  but  they  do  not  address  the  need  for  more  comprehensive,  Government-led 
coordination. Such coordination is essential for prioritizing and sequencing investments across 
all national programs.  
 
39.  Limited Capacity at Provincial Administration. Provincial administrations are critical 
elements in the Government’s efforts to implement effective service delivery and to fulfill the 
future ANDS. Currently, public spending is undertaken through provincial representatives of line 
ministries. There is limited capacity to assess how the public spending of the line ministries can 
fulfill key provincial development goals. There is also limited stakeholder consultation to ensure 
provincial needs are reflected in national budget formulation. Any effective roll-out of public 
goods and services will thereby imply strengthening provincial administrations to increase their 
involvement in development planning over the medium term and in budget formulation over the 
longer term. The creation of a parliament and provincial councils is expected to lead to further

10 
reforms of provincial administrations and to strengthen their role in provincial socioeconomic 
development. 
 
3.  Public Financial Management 
 
40.  The  legislative  framework  which  governs  public  financial  management  (PFM)  in 
Afghanistan is composed of numerous laws and regulations that are applied selectively and do 
not  clearly  delineate  PFM  roles  and  responsibilities.  Moreover,  contradictory  provisions 
undermine  compliance  and  its  implementation.  To  address  this,  a  Public  Finance  and 
Expenditure  Management  (PFEM)  Law  was  approved  in  June  2005.  The  law  covers  the 
Government sector13 (although rules for center–province relationships will have to be clarified 
under regulations to be developed). It (i) provides clearly defined PFM roles and responsibilities, 
(ii) requires adequate reporting, (iii) provides for independent review, and (iv) holds public 
officials  accountable.  The  Government’s  program  of  financial  management  improvements, 
which is supported by the World Bank’s recently completed Public Finance Review, will have 
far-reaching consequences for the processes (recording, accounting, and reporting) of financial 
transactions over the next few years. 
 
41.  The  MOF  is  the  lead  agency  in  the  development  of  the  Government’s  financial 
management system. It is responsible for budget preparation, execution and control, revenue 
administration  (customs  and  non-customs  revenue),  payroll,  accounting,  financial  reporting, 
debt management, cash management, as well as a range of functions for Government asset 
administration. To date, the MOF has focused on critical elements of the Government’s financial 
management system. Since 2002, public financial management roles, rules, and information 
have evolved, and significant steps have been undertaken with donor support to implement 
emergency arrangements for public financial management and to build capacity in the key areas 
of budget implementation and treasury, procurement, and external auditing.  
  
42.  Accordingly,  information  technology  (IT)  applications  have  been  developed  and 
implemented to support: (i) the national budget process; (ii) treasury functions, which comprise 
budget execution and control, accounting, and financial reporting; (iii) payroll; (iv) customs 
administration; and (v) some functions of asset administration and management. Each of these 
has been developed as a separate management information system (MIS) with varying degrees 
of coordination. They operate for all practical purposes as separate systems. In addition to the 
MOF’s  efforts,  many  line  ministries  are  investing  in  IT  to  support  their  specific  financial 
management requirements. As the Government moves into the next phase of development, it 
becomes critical that a strategic and structured approach to the investment and implementation 
of  Government  financial  management  IT  systems  is  undertaken.  A  strategic  approach  is 
required to enable appropriate and cost effective investment, and to avoid duplication of effort. 
The adoption of a strategic approach is of particular importance now, with the extension of 
existing systems to the line ministries and provinces under consideration.  
 
43.  Treasury Management. Effective cash management14 remains a major challenge in 
Afghanistan. Cash flow forecasts are prepared for the operating budget for the fiscal year and 
updated monthly. However, revenue and expenditure projections are drawn from targets rather 
than from historical patterns and procurement plans, and have resulted in large idle balances in

Moreover, development budgets are for the most part outside cash planning and consolidation

44.  Effective  cash  management  requires  synchronization  of  cash  flow  needs  and 
borrowing,15  to  avoid  unnecessary  public  debt  charges.  However,  there  is  no  formal  debt 
strategy,  and  the  MOF  has  to  develop  capacity  to  support  debt  sustainability  analyses. 
Spreadsheet records of debt are maintained and reports on debt stock and service are prepared 
periodically. However, these do not include records on guarantees, or support budgeting of debt 
service for existing loans, forecasting for new loans and disbursements, analysis under different 
scenarios, or allows for checks on reporting and costing. As the debt register is not integrated 
with  the  treasury  system,  (i.e.,  the  Afghanistan  management  information  system  [AFMIS]) 
reliance is placed on manual checks for data integrity, manual reporting, and audit trails.   
 
45.  Cash  management  needs  to  ensure  that  there  are  no imbalances resulting from  a 
sudden overrun on expenditures or shortfall in revenues. While the overriding “no overdraft” 
policy is a safeguard against accumulated imbalances, there have been occasions when the 
Treasury Department has had to draw down on the proceeds from budgetary support loans in 
order to correct a mismatch between expenditure and receipts,. More recently, a prudential 
reserve has been introduced in the budget. Despite this reserve, as there is no predictable and 
separate revenue stream (in the absence of a market for treasury management instruments, 
such as treasury bills, in Afghanistan), using part of loan proceeds as a revenue buffer may be 
justified.  However,  the  current  system  is  far  from  an  ideal  solution  and  entails  significant 
opportunity costs on the use of available loan funds.  
 
D.  Lessons Learned 
 
  1.  Development Effectiveness 
 
46.  In general, development effectiveness principles recognize the Government’s central 
role in managing the development process.16 This implies Government ownership from the 
national  development  strategy  to  the  public  expenditure  review  and  public  investment 
programming. Although there are limits on “ownership” in postconflict economies, the sooner 
well-run economic management is transferred to the Government, the greater is the scope for 
Government accountability for use of resources and overall results. In Afghanistan, where about 
30% of total planned spending is channeled through the operational budget and where some 
Government functions are almost fully outsourced to NGOs, donor assistance should strive to 
build capacity to ensure greater ownership.

47.  More  effective  Government  ownership  of  economic  management  (supported  by  a 
private-sector-led growth strategy) requires institutional strengthening, in particular, developing 
(i)  a medium-term strategy to achieve development objectives consistent with the institutional 
vision; (ii) human resource policies that are consistent with results-based management, based 
on an incentives framework, and  responsive to changing circumstances; and (iii) management 
information systems that strengthen transparency and accountability and can facilitate functional 
reforms  and  change  management.  In  Afghanistan,  provincial  administrations  and  local 
government, where capacity during the years of war was almost completely destroyed, are 
particularly weak. Reforms with the objective of extending public goods and services nation-
wide will need to address these institutional constraints.   
 
48.  Reforms will need to be supported by strong communication policy both with regard to 
outside stakeholders (why is it important to change?) and insiders (how will staff benefit from 
change?). 
 
49.  FMPARP seeks to strengthen Government ownership of the budget process—ultimately 
the  most  important  policy  instrument—in  order  to  translate  Government  priorities  into 
development projects. Measures will seek to strengthen fiscal management by focusing on 
(i) systems  and  procedures  consistent  with  international  standards;  and  (ii)  strategic 
development  through  human  resource  practices  and  modern  integrated  IT  systems.  The 
proposed grant under FMPARP will play a critical role in training and capacity building, drawing 
on Government officials and other domestic consultants to be retained under special public 
administration reform programs.  
 
2.  Sequencing of Reforms 
 
50.  The  World  Bank  has  analyzed  the  sequencing  of  public  sector  reforms  for  service 
delivery.17 The largest payoffs result from a few key actions such as (i) setting the framework for 
spending effectively and predictably in line with priorities and ensuring this is well coordinated 
across sectors; (ii) devolving administrative systems so they are close to the end users of public 
goods and services; and (iii) enhancing administrative capacity to manage and implement the 
Government’s policies and priorities efficiently. FMPARP draws on this analysis and recognizes 
that  sustainable  improvements  in  service  delivery  need  to  be  based  on  efficient  revenue 
collection, clear prioritizing of spending, and effective monitoring of impact. Once this foundation 
is in place, there can be more sustainable and targeted reforms for improved service delivery 
under subprogram 2.  
 
  3.  Leveraging Fiscal Management  
 
51.  Drawing on recent work by the IMF,18 building fiscal institutions in postconflict countries 
requires: (i) creating a legal and/or regulatory framework for fiscal management, (ii) establishing

expenditure management. Key strategies include focusing on a large number of intermediate 
measures over the short term that will gradually transform budgetary practices from a crisis 
mode to a more normal state of affairs. Local capacity needs to be built; without appropriate

B.  Important Features 
 
60.  An  important  feature  of  the  cluster  program  is  the  tailoring  of  the  reform  program 
approach to the circumstances in Afghanistan. In view of the sharp institutional constraints, 
FMPARP  carefully  addresses  sequencing  considerations  by  emphasizing  institutional

61.  The  FMPARP  will  serve  to  promote  good  governance  through  such  measures  as 
participatory budgeting, comprehensive and transparent budget formulation and execution, and

corruption and the diversion of resources from intended recipients. This will reassure donors 
and encourage them to channel more resources through the Government budget, in turn, 
leading  to  further  institutional  strengthening  and  state  building,  which  is  essential  to  the

C.  Program Loan 
 
1.  Objectives 
 
62.  The FMPARP will develop systems and procedures—supported by increased capacity—
to improve budget programming, strengthen resource mobilization, develop the civil service and

2.  Goals and Output 
 
63.  FMPARP has three goals, to strengthen (i) fiscal management, (ii) public administration, 
and (iii) public financial management. To achieve the first goal, FMPARP will support improving

the  second  goal,  FMPARP  will  support  strengthening  civil  service  management,  provincial

64.  Following  several  rounds  of  consultation  (see  Appendix  5)  a  list  of  policy

time-bound policy actions are included in Appendix 6. The FMPARP framework is in Appendix 7

3.  Policy Framework and Actions 
 
65.  The program loan (policy component) focuses on key measures to strengthen systems 
and procedures under fiscal management, implementation of the Civil Service Law, and public 
financial management. The proposals are fully consistent with the thrust of Government reforms 
as identified in the Ministry of Finance vision paper and other Government priority programs.  
 
a.  Strengthening Fiscal Management 
 
i.  Improving the Budgeting Framework 
 
66.  Proper  Budget  Classification.  The  Public  Finance  and  Expenditure  Management 
(PFEM) Law was enacted in June 2005. FMPARP will support implementation of the law, which 
prescribes roles and responsibilities and broad policies and guidelines consistent with sound 
budget practices and overall financial management. It will support the preparation of the FY2007 
budget, which will be based on a new chart of accounts that will present expenditures according 
to  standard  government  financial  statistics  (GFS)  classifications,  including  classification  of 
functions of government (COFOG). Subprogram 1 of FMPARP will work with the Government to 
reconcile  the  current  classification  system,  which  accounts  for  operating  expenditures  by 
“ministry” and development expenditures by “programs.”  
 
67.  Developing a Medium-Term Budgeting Framework. The failure to link policy making 
and planning with budgeting may be the most important factor contributing to poor budgeting 
outcomes. MOF is seeking to develop a closer link between the ANDS, the PIPs, and the 
budget.  Budget  programming  will  aim  to  (i)  link  budget  formulation  with  underlying 
macroeconomic trends, (ii) allocate resource envelopes across sectors, (iii) prioritize PIPs, 
(iv) strengthen analysis to develop public expenditure policies, and (v) improve evaluation of 
budget outcomes to achieve the goals of the ANDS.   
 
68.  MOF is focusing on the preparation of multi-year frameworks, including a medium-term 
fiscal framework (MTFF) that sets expenditure and revenue targets over a 3-year horizon and 
can  base  planned  expenditure  on  anticipated  revenues.  The  introduction  of  3-year  rolling 
expenditure  and  revenue  projections  under  the  MTFF  (Appendix  2)  will  underpin  the 
development of a medium-term budgeting framework (MTBF) under subprogram 1 (Appendix 
9). The MTBF is a useful public expenditure management tool that will ensure transparency and 
accountability, and support better-targeted resource allocations and more effective expenditure.  
 
69.  Subprogram 1 will support the establishment of a fiscal coordination committee (FCC) 
that will link the various MOF departments involved in the budget process. Subprogram 2 will 
build on the MTBF in order to achieve (i) accurate revenue forecasts and aggregate resource 
envelope, (ii) effective allocation of budgets to line ministries, and (iii) accurate expenditure 
monitoring. Subprogram 2 will support the adoption of best practices in defining expenditure 
ceilings for spending units that are consistent with the multi-year framework. 
  
70.  Integrating  Operating  and  Development  Budgets.  A  better  integration  of  the 
operating and development budgets is another key step to improving budget outcomes. The 
Government is committed to achieving a unified budget by FY2011.  
 
71.  Developing capacity to unify the budget will be a major challenge for Treasury officials.  
It will require moving from the current stage, where the budget is mainly based on donor-driven

17 
expenditure, to the next stage, where donor programs are channeled into the general budget 
through the TSA. In other words, the Treasury will have to manage to a move from a “supply-
driven” approach to development expenditure to a “demand-driven” approach. This will require 
clear  articulation  of  sector  development  strategies  and  coordinated  sector-based  financial 
planning that is linked to the medium-term expenditure framework, as well as a responsive 
central–provincial fiscal system. To begin this transformation, subprogram 1 will support budget 
preparation  measures  that  will  identify  the  operating  costs  of  development  projects  in  the 
operating budget using a multi-year framework. Subprogram 2 will improve the alignment of 
operating and development budgets by establishing the budget preparation guidelines that will 
lead to a fully unified national budget. 
 
72.  Avoiding  Fiscal  Risks.  Effectively  managing  fiscal  risks  is  part  of  sound  fiscal 
management. Fiscal risks typically arise from developments that are not properly accounted for 
(e.g., a sudden surge in oil prices or a state-owned enterprise that defaults on a payment). 
Corrective  actions  can  be  taken  through,  for  example,  midyear  budget  reviews  and 
supplementary budgets. The strengthening of financial reporting requirements is a prerequisite 
for safeguarding against fiscal risks. State-owned enterprises will be required to strengthen 
financial reporting. Following on from an inventory of public enterprises and other Government 
entities  (including  Government  controlled  funds),  subprogram  1  will  establish  a  system  to 
monitor revenues of these entities as well as subsidies and transfers to them. Subprogram 2 will 
consolidate  these  entities  and  funds  through  closures  and  mergers.  Under  subprogram  2, 
guidelines on contingent liabilities, including guarantees, will be drawn up.  
 
73.  Moving  towards  a  Participatory  Budget  Process. Currently,  civil  society  and  the 
private sector have no formal role in budget formulation or in the development of public policy. 
However, in view of their significant involvement in funding and implementing the external 
funded budget, donors and NGOs are asked to provide information on the following year’s 
expenditure plans, and their link to public investment priorities. The consultative groups (CGs) 
provide forums for discussion on development programs and associated budgets, and these 
have implications for succeeding operating budgets. With the establishment of Parliament, the 
degree of scrutiny of the FY2006 and subsequent budgets will be much greater than in the past. 
Greater stakeholder consultation will be encouraged to strengthen overall support and ensure 
swift approval of the budget. Subprogram 1 will help the Government to draft a time-bound 
strategy and action plan that includes extensive consultation with key stakeholders in the budget 
process. Subprogram 2 will support approval and implementation of this action plan. 
 
74.  Separating Revenue and Treasury Functions at Moustufiats. To strengthen lines of 
responsibilities and reporting requirements from the provinces to the center, the MOF proposes 
separating revenue functions from payment and treasury functions. This will strengthen fiduciary 
responsibilities and reduce the influence of “captive” interests at the provincial level. It will 
thereby (i) limit revenue leakage, and (ii) ensure consistency of expenditures according to the 
policy priorities set forth in the national budget. Subprogram 1 will support the preparation of 
guidelines on the role of the moustufiats of the MOF, including clear lines of responsibilities on 
revenue collection functions at provincial offices and at the Customs and Revenue Departments 
at MOF, and on payment and treasury functions at provincial offices and at the Director General 
of  Treasury.  Subprogram  1  will  also  prepare  a  time-bound  action  plan  for  phased 
implementation  of  the  guidelines,  starting  with  seven  priority  moustufiats  and  covering  all 
provinces by the time the guidelines are finalized under subprogram 2.  
 
75.  Enhancing Capacity for Fiscal Analysis. A fiscal policy unit (FPU) has recently been 
established within the MOF. In line with international best practice, subprogram 1 will support

18 
the  strengthening  of  the  FPU  consisting  of  technical  experts  who  can  provide  objective 
assessments to the Minister of Finance.25 The FPU will be charged with preparing an MTFF—
and eventually an MTBF—that is consistent with the underlying macroeconomic framework and 
that will underscore the budget process. The principal responsibilities of the FPU will include 
(i) general budget year and medium-term fiscal trend analyses, (ii) assessments of the fiscal 
sustainability of public expenditure policies, and, eventually, (iii) debt sustainability analyses.  
 
76.  In addition to the main tasks referred to above, there is an urgent need for the FPU to 
analyze the budgetary implications of the pay and grading system currently under review and its 
impact on the wage and pensions bills. The FPU could provide input on the implications of the 
eventual phased-in integration of expenditure on the national army—which is currently funded 
from external sources—into the national budget. FPU could also provide analysis on revenues 
and  expenditures  by  province,  as  the  budget  process  will  need  to  address  subnational 
considerations, following the establishment of Parliament and provincial councils. FPU will also 
need to consider how revenue transfers to the provinces can be identified, evaluated, and 
monitored. Under subprogram 2, consideration will be given to preparing a policy paper to 
develop an operating framework for inter-governmental revenue transfers.  
 
77.  Introducing Performance Monitoring. At present, there are no performance indicators 
and limited capacity for budget evaluation or for determining whether public policy outcomes are 
being achieved. The budget process and, in particular, expenditures, tend to follow simple 
incremental rules based on notional growth rates. Subprogram 1 will support the piloting of 
result-based indicators in priority sectors such as energy, transport, and agriculture with a view 
to moving towards a more result-based budgeting system. Towards the end of subprogram 2, 
and subject to progress achieved, MOF may be able to link performance indicators to some 
budget appropriations. 
 
ii.  Improving the Public Investment Program 
 
78.  The public investment program (PIP) is the key link between the ANDS and the budget. 
Accordingly, successful achievement of the goals and objectives of the ANDS will depend on 
the formulation and successful implementation of the PIPs under the NPPs. The national priority 
programs (NPPs) will therefore need to establish clear criteria based on economic returns, 
social  welfare  considerations,  or  other  objective  criteria  to  determine  prioritization  of  PIP. 
However,  ultimately  the  Budget  Committee  will  decide  on  which  PIPs  are  included  in  the 
Budget. Subprogram 1 will support the strengthening of the Budget Committee so it can (i) 
identify investment programs and projects that are consistent with ANDS, (ii) establish a clear 
ranking system for such programs and projects, (iii) classify the implementation of individual 
programs and projects according to an overall risk assessment, and (iv) publish results.   
 
79.  Subprogram 1 will support efforts by the Budget Committee and MOF to (i) evaluate the 
contribution  of  PIPs  to  the  MDGs,  (ii)  develop  a  performance  monitoring  and  evaluation 
framework for ANDS and PIPs, and (iii) publish an analysis of results. Subprogram 2 will 
consider how performance can be linked to expenditure, and, in particular, how a performance-
based  fund  release  system  for  NPP  allocations  can  be  introduced.  This  will  enable  the 
Government  to  improve  its  assessment  of  policy  interventions  and  eventually  link  its 
development policies with expenditure and investment priorities and fiscal policies.

ii.  Improving Provincial Administrations and Service Delivery

Government needs to develop a strategy on the role of Government and NGOs in service 
delivery. As a first step, a law governing the NGOs was approved in July 2005. The law

able to provide alternatives, a better balance may be reached over the medium term, allowing

c.  Strengthening Public Financial Management 
 
89.  The goal of the public financial management system is to ensure fiduciary standards are 
appropriately implemented. The Afghan public and international donors need to feel secure that 
Government resources and donor funds are being used for the purposes intended and that they 
are subject to appropriate allocation and expenditure controls. An integral part of this goal is 
complying  with  international  standards  of  financial  management,  including  the  use  of 
internationally recognized accounting, auditing, and reporting standards. 
 
i.  Improving  Accountability  and  Transparency  Across 
Government  
 
90.  The PFEM Law lays the foundations for an improved financial accountability framework. 
Subprogram 1 will support measures to strengthen this framework. It will work with MOF and the 
Control and Audit Office (CAO) to develop government operations manuals that contain explicit 
policies, guidelines, and procedures across government. Operations manuals will be prepared 
to support public financial management, including planning and budgeting, accounting and 
financial reporting, and internal audit. The initial focus will be on the broad dissemination of the 
manuals, accompanied by training. As they are implemented more widely, the focus under 
subprogram  2  will  then  shift  to  the  internal  audit  process  and  assessment  of  procedural 
compliance and the reliability of internal control measures. A risk-based internal audit strategy 
that identifies high-risk activities and government entities will be needed.  
 
91.  Integration  of  the  budget  and  accounting  systems  will  ensure  the  sustainability  of

      ii.  Strengthening Treasury Management  
 
94.  Strengthening cash and debt management under subprogram 1 will improve the orderly 
execution of the budget by making resources available in a more timely way and reducing public 
debt charges. Cash management will be strengthened through the integration of cash flow 
management system with the treasury accounting system (AFMIS). This will enable improved
