V.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Benefits 
 
117.  The  FMPARP  will  strengthen  public  finances  in  Afghanistan,  including  improving 
capacity to carry out the reform agenda according to the policy outcomes identified under 
Section IV.  
 
118.  It will develop an enabling environment within the MOF and IARCSC and gradually 
across  provincial  counterparts  that  will  improve  capacity  to  (i)  collect  revenues  efficiently, 
(ii) direct public resources to meet priority needs, and (iii) monitor the flow of resources and 
evaluate the impact of public spending. 
 
119.  FMPARP will support fiscal management and public administration reforms that are key 
pillars of the Government’s overall reform program. These reforms will enable the country to 
manage the transition from responding to emergency needs and recovery-related growth to 
long-term  sustainable  development.  Improvements  in  the  budget  process,  financial 
management, and fiduciary control mechanisms are likely to encourage more donors to channel 
funding  through  the  Government  budget.  This  will,  in  turn,  lead  to  further  institutional 
strengthening and state building, which is essential to the consolidation of peace.  
 
120.  FMPARP will encourage the Government to adopt a more participatory approach to the 
budgeting process, enhancing ownership, and promoting more efficient resource allocation and 
the achievement of the MDGs. A more efficient allocation of public resources will be essential 
for poverty reduction. Beneficiaries of public goods and services will include lower-income 
groups  and  individuals  below  the  poverty  line  (see  Appendix  14  for  the  summary  poverty 
reduction and social strategy). 
 
121.  Direct beneficiaries will include the Government itself, which will benefit from time-bound 
policy actions that will lead to defined outcomes. Other beneficiaries will include government 
officials who will gain valuable experience from working with consultants in implementing the 
reform agenda and who will benefit from direct training under the capacity building component

29 
of the FMPARP. NGOs will benefit over the longer term, as a system of standards will be 
developed under subprogram 2 to strengthen the outsourcing of service delivery. 
 
122.  Over  the  longer  term,  the  policy  reforms  will  be  deepened  under  subprogram  2. 
FMPARP  will  serve  to  strengthen  governance  in  Afghanistan,  including  supporting  greater 
involvement of the state in raising revenues and financing development needs. Taxpayers and 
importers  will  benefit  from  clearer,  simplified,  and  more  balanced  tax  and  customs 
administration. In addition, the people most dependent on the provision of public goods and 
services, including people living in remote areas, should expect an eventual improvement in the 
quality of these services as a result of reduced waste, duplication, and other nonproductive use 
of public resources.   
 
123.  FMPARP is classified as category C under ADB’s environmental classification system. 
Its environmental impact is expected to be minimal. FMPARP will not trigger ADB’s policies on 
involuntary resettlement or indigenous peoples. 
 
B.  Risks  
 
124.  Risks to FMPAR are multiple and can be classified according to the Program’s ability to 
affect or mitigate these risks.  
 
125.  External risks include: (i) security, (ii) political, and (iii) macroeconomic risks. Internal 
risks include: (i) capacity constraints, (ii) governance, and (iii) donor coordination.   
 
126.  Security concerns pose the largest risk. A worsening security situation would have many 
impacts  on  the  FMPARP,  including  limiting  extending  reforms  to  the  subnational  level  of 
government.  If  the  security  situation  deteriorates,  operations  will  be  restricted  and  fielding 
consults and monitoring will be more difficult. Political risks appear to be contained, following 
successful parliamentary and provincial elections. However, in a more politicized environment, 
decisive policy decisions may not be based on technical merit alone. Macroeconomic risks have 
decreased, following significant progress in building supporting infrastructure to ensure effective 
macroeconomic  management  and  overall  improvement  to  the  macroeconomic  stability 
framework.  
 
127.  Capacity  constraints  are  the  most  significant  internal  risks,  because  of  the  limited 
availability of skilled resources to implement the reform program. Governance risks include the 
power of vested interests. Revenue administration officials may be co-opted by interests that 
refuse to embrace change or by enterprises that want to override the legal system. There may 
also be scope for corruption. Donor coordination risks are acute in Afghanistan, where there is a 
significant donor presence in most ministries. Unless there is strong Government ownership of 
the reforms, combined with well coordinated programs, there is a risk of duplication ineffective 
assistance. 
 
128.  These  risks  will  be  mitigated  in  the  following  ways.  FMPARP  will  develop  human 
resource management  policies across key ministries that would directly address the weak 
capacity. The grant component is particularly designed to enhance capacity and institutional 
development. 
 
129.  In addition, the policy framework design has factored in potential risks by presenting a 
tailored  set  of  policy  reforms  focused  on  developing  institutional  foundations  under 
subprogram 1 and ensuring these are built upon in subprogram 2.

30 
 
130.  FMPARP  will  support  efforts  to  reduce  macroeconomic  risks  by  improving  revenue 
collection and supporting measures to improve fiscal discipline. In addition, enhancing revenue 
mobilization will reduce the risk of disruption and dependency on foreign assistance over the 
medium term, as other development challenges outside Afghanistan may arise.    
 
131.  Safeguards  include  coordinated  and  complementary  reform  programs  supported  by 
other donors (para. 57).

SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  The Budget 
 
1.  The national budget in Afghanistan comprises a core and an external budget. The core 
budget reflects funds that are channeled through the Government’s treasury account, including 
Government revenue collection and semi- or fully discretionary donor funding through budgetary 
support programs that covers mostly operating expenditures. The external budget is wholly 
donor-funded and is channeled directly to consulting firms, nongovernment organizations, and 
other implementing parties. The external budget covers the development budget and operating 
costs associated with capital spending.   
 
2.  The  first  post-conflict  national  budget  for  Afghanistan  (fiscal  year  [FY]  2005)  was 
adopted by presidential decree in June 2004—about 3 months after the start of the fiscal year 
(FY) on 21 March. This was followed by a midyear review of the national development budget 
approved in December 2004. The Government approved its operating budget for FY2006 on 15 
March 2005, before the start of the fiscal year. This was an important achievement, as it 
enabled the Government to address payment delays and operating expenditure arrears that 
occurred the previous year. An interim development budget was approved on 2 April 2005 to 
ensure continuity of funding to ongoing development projects. The final development budget 
was approved in June 2005 to incorporate additional donor-funded projects. A midyear review of 
the FY2006 budget was finalized in November 2005. 
 
3.  The external development budget is a commitment of resources based on a list of 
individual projects that are classified under three pillars: pillar 1—human capital; pillar 2—
infrastructure; and pillar 3—enabling environment, for development. These three pillars are 
broken into 16 consultative working groups composed of government officials and donors, and 6 
crosscutting advisory groups. Because of differences in donors’ budget cycles, commitments 
are not available before the start of Afghanistan’s fiscal year. As a result, the resource envelope 
remains an indicative figure. This explains why an interim development budget is approved 
before the final development budget.   
 
4.  In the revised FY2006 budget, the total planned expenditure is estimated at $5.7 billion 
(approximately 82% of GDP), of which $4.8 billion (84% of total) will be for the development 
budget and $693 million (14% of total) will be for the operating budget (Table A2.1). Of the total 
planned development expenditure, approximately $1 billion or 21% will be disbursed through the 
core budget and $2.2 billion or 46% directly by donors to implementing agencies, leaving a 
funding gap of $1.6 billion or of 33% of the total. According to the revised FY2006 budget, 58% 
of the total budget is allocated for pillar 3 (up from 48% last year), compared with 27% for pillar 
2, and 14% for pillar 1. Allocations for both pillars 1 and 2 have declined since last year.    
 
5.  About two-thirds of the operating budget is funded by domestic revenues and the other 
third from ARTF and LOTFA (Table A2.2). The operating budget is nominally in balance1 and 
fiscal expansion remains subject to prudent growth rates. This reflects a limited absorptive 
capacity, unstable security conditions, and an overstretched cadre of qualified civil servants. At 
the same time, this shows potential for domestic revenue generation. A contingency provision of 
nearly $17 million is meant to operate as a reserve for unplanned expenditures within the year, 
and to maintain fiscal discipline. There is also a multiyear reserve of $183 million for the funding

B.   Expenditure  
 
6.  Under the core budget (Table A3.3), wages and salaries comprise 62% of operating 
expenditures. In the past, wages and salaries had been growing at above 30% per year and 
contributing to mounting fiscal stress. The rapid expansion of priority reform and restructuring, 
and the spillover effects on wages and salaries of other civil servants, in part to offset steep 
increases  in  housing  rentals,  may  explain  these  rapid  increases.  Purchase  of  goods  and 
services  are  the  next  most  important  item,  accounting  for  close  to  20%  of  operating 
expenditures. Finally, transfers and subsidies, and pension payments remain small at under 3% 
of operating expenditure, reflecting the limited safety nets in Afghanistan. 
 
7.  According to the FY2006 midyear budget review, operating expenditure for FY2006 is 
projected to increase to 10% of GDP from 9.4% of GDP in FY2005. This is a contained 
increase, in line with the operating principles on fiscal prudence set forth in the budget, and 
comes against the backdrop of a 22% increase in nominal GDP and a 19% increase in domestic 
revenue. Planned development expenditure under the midyear FY 2006 budget is $4.8 billion, 
compared with $4.4 billion at the time of budget approval.  
 
8.  The budget for FY2006 was developed under a new chart of accounts that will allow 
functional classification according to expenditure items in the following year. In the meantime, 
operating expenditures are accounted for by the ministries, while development expenditure is 
reported by program. The breakdown of expenditures in the FY2006 operating budget reveals 
that the Afghan National Army and National Police and Enforcement account for approximately 
43% of the total operating expenditure of ministries and agencies. This is followed by education 
and vocational training at approximately 20%, and health and nutrition at below 5%. 
 
C.   Revenues 
 
9.  The total operating revenues for FY 2006 is projected at $816 million. This comprises 
domestic revenue (tax and non-tax) collection, projected at $468 million (equivalent to 6.8% of 
GDP),  ARTF  funds  for  $280  million,  and  LOTFA  funds  for  $68  million.  Funding  to  and 
allocations from the Counter-Narcotics Trust Fund are still to be determined. Total revenue in 
FY2006 is projected to increase by 46% compared to the previous year.  
 
10.  MOF is currently implementing a five-year tax administration plan with donor funding 
available for the first 3 years. Under the plan, the large-taxpayer office will become operational. 
The office will remove impediments to revenue collection by removing nuisance taxes and 
eliminating tax holidays and other exemptions. In addition, tax identification numbers (TIN) will 
be issued more vigorously to facilitate compliance with and enforcement of tax laws. As of 
September 2005, nearly 19,000 TINs have been issued in Kabul and close to 6,000 in the 
provinces. Money changers, customs brokers licensing processes, and motor vehicle purchase 
will now require TIN registration.  
 
11.  An amendment to the Revenue Law was approved in May 2005. Under the law, the 
corporate tax rate is set at 20% for all businesses. Income tax is set at a two-tier structure of 
10% for annual income of up to AF1.2 million and 20% for income over AF1.2 million. The tax-
free income tax threshold is set at AF150,000 per annum. Withholding tax on wages will be

1.  The National Development Framework (NDF) focuses on three pillars: pillar 1—security and 
human  development,  pillar  2—physical  infrastructure,  and  pillar  3—enabling  environment  for 
development. The NDF contains a list of 16 national priority programs (NPPs), with one consultative 
group (CG) for each national program. Additionally, six advisory groups have been established for 
crosscutting issues (gender, environment, humanitarian affairs, human rights, monitoring and evaluation, 
and counter-narcotics). The CGs consists of representatives of ministries, donors, and implementing 
partners. The main tasks of the CGs are to (i) advise the Government on the development of long-term 
strategic policies for the 16 NPPs, including identifying resources necessary for policy development; (ii) 
coordinate the implementation of programs and projects through the annual budget cycle; (iii) monitor 
and evaluate implementation; and (iv) facilitate information sharing. The Ministry of Finance chairs the 
Consultative Group Standing Committee (CGSC).

2.  The performance of the CGs has been varied and several reviews have taken place. While some

THE MEDIUM-TERM BUDGETING FRAMEWORK 
 
A.  The Medium-Term Budgeting Framework and Results-Based Budget System 
 
1.  The  medium-term  budgeting  framework  (MTBF)  is  a  useful  public  expenditure 
management tool to shape the budget process, ensure transparency and accountability, and 
support  better-targeted  resource  allocations  and  more  efficient  expenditure  outcomes.  The 
attached figure briefly describes the MTBF.  
 
2.  The Need for Accurate Revenue Forecasts and an Aggregate Resource Envelope. 
The resource and expenditure allocations of commitments should be sustainable in the medium 
term. This implies that resource allocation should not exceed the aggregate of public revenues 
and “sustainable”1 borrowing. Accordingly, estimates and forecasts for public revenues should 
be accurate, consistent, and unbiased. 
 
3.  Allocating Budgets to Line Ministries. In a traditional budgetary management system, 
budget allocations to line ministries tend to be closely tied to previous annual allocations, with 
ministries tending to spend all of their budgets to avoid potential cuts in the following years. 
However, under the MTBF, budgetary allocations to line ministries are driven by the broader 
policy objectives of the Government, as guided by the national development strategy or its 
equivalent. Under this MTBF, the line ministries must prioritize expenditure options to meet 
policy objectives. The Ministry of Finance (MOF)—at times in coordination with Ministry of 
Economy  and  Planning—must  assess  the  various  prioritized  budgetary  requests  from  line 
ministries within the context and constraints of the aggregate resource envelope. The decision 
of  the  MOF  is  based  on  objective  criteria—proposed  expenditures  delivering  broad  policy 
objectives  of  the  Government—rather  than  on  the  subjective  outcomes  of  face-to-face 
negotiations. 
 
4.  The  new  budgetary  allocation  process  changes  the  relationship,  roles,  and 
responsibilities of MOF and the line ministries. Instead of simply enforcing expenditure control, 
MOF oversees and coordinates expenditure policy. The line ministries enjoy greater freedom to 
formulate their own budgets, while becoming more responsible for ensuring that expenditure 
programs deliver the desired outputs effectively and efficiently. 
 
5.  The  Need  for  Effective  and  Accurate  Expenditure  Monitoring.  Traditional 
expenditure systems emphasize ex-post expenditure monitoring. In contrast, public expenditure 
reviews under MTBF focus on whether the funds have been spent efficiently and according to 
the original budget, and on assessing whether outcomes were delivered or objectives achieved. 
In this context, the MTBF budgeting system must be linked to the expenditure monitoring 
system though the budget classification system. This allows actual expenditures under this 
classification to be mapped back to the original budget. 
 
6.  Feedback of Learning and Development of Next Year’s Budget. Each year’s budget 
process will result in new experiences and lessons learned by both the MOF and line ministries, 
and  with  reference  to  both  expenditure  monitoring  and  public  expenditure  reviews.  These 
lessons will feed back into the development of the following years’ budget.

THE GOVERNMENT’S VISION OF THE PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION IN AFGHANISTAN 
 
1.  After  years  of  war  and  centralized  state  control,  management  and  administrative 
systems and skills in Afghanistan are lacking, and Government infrastructure has been severely 
damaged. The Government’s success in implementing policies depends substantially on the 
competence, efficiency, and effectiveness of the civil service. A concerted and focused program 
for the renewal and transformation of public administration started in 2000 to remedy these 
shortcomings.   
 
2.  The Independent Administrative Reform and Civil Service Commission (IARCSC) has 
been designated as the focal point for a comprehensive and strategic approach for rebuilding 
the public service involving the whole Government. The approach is based on the following 
principles: (i) the civil service must be (and must be perceived to be) loyal to the Government 
and the people of Afghanistan; (ii) short-term priorities must be tackled first and urgently, and 
longer-term and deeper reforms must be initiated; and (iii) implementation will be undertaken 
collaboratively, with close cooperation between IARCSC and other key agencies.  
 
3.  The public administration reform (PAR) program is expected to build a sound, ethical, 
and lawful public administration that can contribute to the future peace, stability, and economic 
prosperity of Afghanistan, and the reduction of poverty among the Afghan people. The specific 
objectives of the PAR program are the following: 
(i)  Establish  a  sound  legal  framework  for  a  professional,  ethical,  equitable  and 
politically impartial civil service. 
(ii)  Establish  effective  civil  service  management  systems  to  attract,  retain  and 
motivate qualified employees on the basis of merit. 
(iii)  Develop  functional  structures  and  administrative  procedures  that  enable  the 
Government to fulfill its commitments. 
(iv)  Develop managerial and administrative capacity within the civil service. 
 
4.  The immediate actions taken in the first phase of the PAR program have provided some 
stability to the public sector and arrested further deterioration. It has also paved the way for the 
medium to longer-term strategy, with planning undertaken for institutional reform and capacity-
building, “pay and grading” reforms, reform of personnel and financial management policies and 
procedures, machinery of Government reforms, and Government infrastructure improvements.  
 
5.  In the short term, there has been concrete progress on (i) drafting a new Civil Service 
Law; (ii) initial restructuring and upgrading of critical Government functions; (iii) paying an 
interim  additional  allowance  for  specified  posts  in  departments  that  carry  out  urgent 
restructuring and reform of critical functions; and (iv) building the capacity and resources of the 
IARCSC to enable it to fulfill its mandate. Initial work has been undertaken in developing 
modern  personnel  management  policies  and  practices;  clarifying  central  roles  and 
responsibilities for administrative reform; establishing requirements for a long-term civil service 
management  and  administration  training  facility;  and  improving  policy  formulation  and 
machinery of Government mechanisms. 
 
6.  The Government is conscious that Afghanistan’s long administrative tradition stretches 
back many years before the conflicts and turbulence of recent years. In implementing the reform 
program, the Government is building on the best aspects of these traditions, while introducing 
modern policies and practices that will serve the country well in the future. The Government also 
recognizes that most civil servants themselves are keen to see improvements, and is actively

CONSIDERATIONS FOR MOVING TOWARD A STRATEGIC APPROACH TO

1.  Substantial savings can be achieved by adopting a standard platform for software and 
hardware to be implemented across all areas of government. Use of defined software for shared 
financial  management  functions  across  ministries  and  provinces,  including  budgeting, 
accounting, payroll, procurement, and project management, will benefit from volume discounts. 
In addition, shared use of hardware—multifunctional terminals, servers, video-satellite (VSAT) 
connections, etc., will substantially reduce the overall requirement for hardware investments 
(which already have a relatively short economic life). The Government, with donor support, has 
already invested a significant amount in software, software customization and implementation 
support, hardware, and connectivity to support government financial management functions. To 
roll out applications to the line ministries and provinces will require much more.  
2.  To achieve savings and facilitate the integration of systems and databases, government-
wide standards for software and hardware need to be defined and adopted, and an overall 
system  architecture  for  the  hardware  infrastructure  required  to  connect  the  ministries  and 
provinces outlined. The Ministry of Commerce, with the support of USAID, is spearheading this 
initiative and has already presented a proposal to the cabinet for a national steering committee 
for information and communication technology to be established for this purpose. The MOC has 
also  developed  a  plan  for  basic  hardware  to  support  connectivity  across  ministries  and 
provinces, which it is the process of implementing.

utilized.  The  existing  systems  have  been  successfully  established  and  are  operational. 
Moreover,  they  serve  as  the  basic  foundation  for  the  Government’s  existing  financial 
management and financial control systems. Thus, options that can be expanded or built upon 
existing systems to the greatest degree possible need to be identified and assessed. This will 
require a critical review of the existing systems, the level of functionality that is presently 
supported, and the level of functionality that is anticipated to meet the Government’s short- to 
medium-term needs that, in turn, will serve as the platform for long-term needs. The Ministry of 
Finance with the support of the World Bank, is in the process of undertaking a study to define an 
overall  systems  architecture  to  support  the  Afghanistan  management  information  system

map for phased implementation of AFMIS.

budget and expenditure performance management, and accounting, financial reporting, and 
internal controls. These options include (i) strengthening the chart of accounts (and use of 
government financial statistics and classification of the functions of Government structured

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Afghanistan:  
 
The Fiscal Management and Public Administration Reform Program (FMPARP) will contribute to poverty 
reduction  by  strengthening  fiscal  management  and  public  administration  and  supporting  reforms  to 
improve fiduciary standards. Improvements in the budget process, financial management processes, and 
fiduciary  control  mechanisms  are  likely  to  encourage  more  donors  to  channel  funding  through  the 
Government  budget.  This  will,  in  turn,  lead  to  further  institutional  strengthening  and  state  building, 
essential to the consolidation of peace and economic recovery. FMPARP will also assist in enabling the 
country to better meet the challenges of the transition from responding to emergency needs and recovery- 
related growth to long-term sustainable development. 
 
The Program encourages the Government to adopt a more participatory approach to the budgeting 
process, enhancing ownership and resource allocation. A more efficient allocation of public resources will 
be essential for poverty reduction. The reforms also aim to strengthen the public investment program with 
clearer prioritization and alignment with the National Development Strategy. This will help the Government 
to more effectively direct public resources to meet priority needs, to monitor the flow of resources and 
evaluate the impact of public spending. Assistance to the fiscal policy unit under FMPARP will also look at 
equity issues in relation to revenue transfers to provinces. 
 
Capacity building under the project grant of FMPARP will assist the Government in deepening its reform 
program and in extending its services beyond Kabul, which is crucial for progress towards poverty 
reduction, consolidation of the peace-building process, and government control. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis         Targeting Classification:    General intervention 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?   
 
There are limited available data on poverty incidence and distribution. Under an ADB TA (Poverty 
Assessment and Socioeconomic and Macroeconomic Statistical Capacity Building)1 an integrated living 
standards survey is currently being conducted with preliminary results expected in mid-2006.  
 
Social  indicators,  while  improving,  are  still  very  low.  Delivery  of  essential  services  remains  largely 
dependent on continued donor support and poses extreme difficulties. Basic services are still largely 
lacking, particularly in remote areas and areas affected by continued unrest. Qualitative information 
suggests that unemployment is a significant problem, especially among the young, which is compounded 
by the extremely low human resource capacity, the continued influx of returning refugees, and high 
population growth rates. A national risk and vulnerability survey conducted in 2003 estimated that per 
capita expenditures in rural areas amounted to $165 per year. The data suggest that 3.5 million of the 17.5 
million Afghans living in rural areas are extremely poor and 10.5 million vulnerable to extreme poverty.
